content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in weeks,” and the heading for row 2 is “L prime of t, in feet per week.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 2. L prime of t is 1.0. Column 2. t is 4. L prime of t is 0.8. Column 3. t is 5. L prime of t is 0.7. Column 4. t is 8. L prime of t is 0.4. Column 5. t is 10. L prime of t is 0.2."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="7em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(weeks)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(feet per week)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>1.0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

The length of a vine during a 12-hour period is given by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="L of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in weeks for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is concave down on the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of the derivative of <math alttext="L"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></math>, <math alttext="L prime of t"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, are given in the table above. At time <math alttext="t equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the length of the vine is 5 feet.

(a)   Use the tangent line approximation for <math alttext="L"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></math> at time <math alttext="t equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to estimate <math alttext="L of 4.3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4.3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the length of the vine at time <math alttext="t equals 4.3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the approximation an overestimate or an underestimate for <math alttext="L of 4.3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4.3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number.

<math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in weeks,” and the heading for row 2 is “L prime of t, in feet per week.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 2. L prime of t is 1.0. Column 2. t is 4. L prime of t is 0.8. Column 3. t is 5. L prime of t is 0.7. Column 4. t is 8. L prime of t is 0.4. Column 5. t is 10. L prime of t is 0.2."><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="7em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(weeks)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(feet per week)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>1.0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.8</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

The length of a vine during a 12-hour period is given by a twice-differentiable function <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="L of t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in feet and <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in weeks for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph of <math alttext="L"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is concave down on the interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 12"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of the derivative of <math alttext="L"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></math>, <math alttext="L prime of t"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, are given in the table above. At time <math alttext="t equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, the length of the vine is 5 feet.

(a)   Use the tangent line approximation for <math alttext="L"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></math> at time <math alttext="t equals 4"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> to estimate <math alttext="L of 4.3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4.3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the length of the vine at time <math alttext="t equals 4.3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the approximation an overestimate or an underestimate for <math alttext="L of 4.3"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4.3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(b)   Use a left Riemann sum with the four subintervals indicated by the data in the table to approximate <math alttext="the integral from, 2 to 10, of, L prime of t, d t"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math>. Indicate units of measure.

(c)   Is the approximation in part (b) an overestimate or an underestimate for <math alttext="the integral from, 2 to 10, of, L prime of t, d t"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(d)   The sum <math alttext="the sum, from k equals 1, to n, of, L prime of, open parenthesis, the fraction 10 k over n, close parenthesis, times the fraction 10 over n"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><munderover><mrow><mo>∑</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></munderover><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> is a right Riemann sum with <math alttext="n"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> subintervals of equal length. The limit of this sum as <math alttext="n"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> goes to infinity can be interpreted as a definite integral. Express the limit as a definite integral.

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Identify a re-expression of mathematical information presented in a given representation
